Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2009 02:42AM mrs_X_Sunneedazee wrote: Sunshine, I know how hard it is to have to loose your hair!  When my cancer was growing again and my doctor wanted to switch me from just Herceptin & Zometa to Taxol, I was almost more devastated that I would be loosing my hair again than the growing cancer.  To add insult to injury, the Taxol didn't even work!!  I then tried Gemzar, and then Xeloda currently, and if I would have gone straight to Gemzar, I wouldn't have lost my hair.   Now the Xeloda doesn't seem to be shrinking any tumors, and I have a nice 1/2" of hair which covers my scalp that has taken 3 months to grow.  So, my onc is thinking of Taxotere, and I probably won't go for it, because I don't want to loose my hair again! I guess the point of all my rambling is that I SO know how you feel, and it SUCKS!!!!  p.s.Janice you look FABULOUS in your wig.  I notice in all of my wig on pictures that my hair has that shiny barbie doll synthetic look.  Oh well.
Posts.Title: Goodbye to hair... again SunshineSmiles heatherpalmerton

Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2008 11:21AM mrs_X_Sunneedazee wrote: Just a quick update, I had my tumor markers ran again this last week, and they came back one doubled and the other tripled.  So, I am officially scheduled to start Taxol again on August 19th.  You would think it would be easier to do this the second time around, but it is actually more difficult.  I dread loosing my hair again---  is that terrible that that is the thing that is most bothering me right now.  I also had terrible stomach problems on the taxol, herceptin combo.  I spent the next 2 days on the toilet after each treatment.  Not to mention I hate the stupid steroids that make me look like a bloated moon faced old man.  At least I get a lot done the night after chemo when I am wired and can't sleep all night!!!!!   It just doesn't seem fair sometimes that I have to do chemo and potty training a 2 year old at the same time.  yikes!!!  We will just have to fight over the toilet!!!  Thanks again for all of your support and help.  I don't know how I would deal with this all without you.
Posts.Title: Progression for me :o( What to do, what to do???? mrs_X_Sunneedazee Barb-FightingBC

Posts.Content: Jul 12, 2008 12:54PM mrs_X_Sunneedazee wrote: Thank you ladies for all of your advice and support.  My thoughts have been so muddled, and my fear has been deep.  All of your kind words and ideas are wonderful, and I appreciate each and every one of you taking the time to help. I did the weekly Taxol, but the combo with herceptin and zometa just made a mess of my stomach.  I had horrible diarrhea for about 3 days after treatment each week.  I am a piano teacher, so the neuropathy I had in my fingers made it difficult to play and teach piano lessons.   I will have to check out that alternative to taxol- abraxane.  I too hate the dexemethazone.  It makes me so jittery and agitated, and can't sleep and I swell up, so I look like a bald fat man.  I posted some before and after pictures on my blog. I have been on Aromasin, but my doctor doesn't think that changing hormonals will make that much of a difference quickly enough.  I asked about radiation, but I have way too many bone mets for that to be effective.  They want to save that for if I am in imminent danger of a bone breaking.  He is quite adamant about not changing treatment drugs from Taxol because we quit that while it was still working, so he strongly believes that I still have some mileage left out of that, and he doesn't want to burn through treatments too quickly.  I have a lot of years to live!!!!!!  I will have my tumor markers ran again in 2 weeks.  If they do another large jump doubling again, then we won't delay the start of Taxol.  However if they only rise a small to moderate amount, we will delay another 3 weeks until August 19th.  We have a family trip planned August 6-12 so I would really want to wait until after that.  My kids go back to school on August 25th.  3 will go all day, and then I will have my kindergartner go half day, and have my 2 year old home with me all day.  I will be able to rest and handle the side effects a lot better once the kids are back in school.  We will just have to cram a whole lot of fun into the next month!!!  We already went to Yellowstone national Park for a week, and that was so beautiful and relaxing.  We plan to go swimming lots, and to the Zoo and the park, and school clothes shopping, and all that other fun stuff.

Posts.Content: Dec 5, 2008 10:53PM mrs_X_Sunneedazee wrote: I did chemo taxol and herceptin and zometa for 5 months, and then had surgery and rads.  I continued with the Herceptin and Zometa throughout rads.  About 8 months after I stopped the Taxol, I had skin mets growing along my scar line.  They looked like angry red rashy welts.  Anyhow, I started the Taxol again, and it took care of the mets, but my mets in my bones and a brain met continued to grow, so I stopped the taxol.  But the point is, at least the sore itchy skin mets went away!  I am hoping that I can find something to work on my bone mets now!  I tried Gemzar-that made me horribly ill, and now I am on Xeloda.  I wonder why your onc didn't have you continue the herceptin during rads?  I hope that your skin mets disappear as quickly as mine did once you begin chemo.  Keep us posted!!!

Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2008 01:23AM mrs_X_Sunneedazee wrote: the truth? With my cancer there was no actual lump, per say.  When I had my mamorgram, I had calcifications all over.  it looked like sugar sprinkled throughout my breast.   My diagnosis (dx) was inflammatory breast cancer.  Of course I had several signs and symptoms of this kind of cancer; red inflamed, thickened skin, discoloration, breast swelling, stabbing pain, orange peel skin, etc etc, I know the waiting is the hardest, when you just want to KNOW so you can go on with your life one way or another.  Just because my outcome was cancer, doesn't mean that your outcome is going to be cancer. When will you get the results for your biopsy?  Try to stay busy and do things to get your mind off of it.  I know, I know, easier said than done, but it does help. Good luck, and please keep us posted!!!!

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2008 10:22PM mrs_X_Sunneedazee wrote: Hi there! I recently did gamma knife for a single brain met.  It sounds like with 3 (I think you said) brain lesions you would be a candidate for gamma knife instead of whole brain radiation.  Gamma knife is a single high dose radaition treatment, and I am glad that I was able to do it, even though it was indeed a traumatic, painful experience.  The actual radiation was fine, it was getting the head frame placed that was painful, and the 4 spots where they screwed it into my head are still a little tender a month later.   I know what you mean about how disappointing it is to loose your hair again.  I too had a cute curly short hair do, and it was a lot more difficult to loose my hair the second time.  I did go buy 3 new cute wigs, that I actually like more than my out of control curls.  they are a lot easier to tame, however they are a little more uncomfortable than having my own hair.   I wish you all the best in your treatment decisions.  It is difficult to learn of brain mets, but it seems like we get used to the bad news, and just keep on keeping on.  It does help to have responsibilites and things to do.  What is the point of being here if we don't still enjoy things, or live life, right!  Best wishes, Amber

Posts.Content: Aug 11, 2009 12:37AM mrs_X_Sunneedazee wrote: Cheryl, I totally understand the feelings that you expressed.  It is so frustrating to try to figure out which steps to make, which treatments to take, and when is enough, enough.  I think that when you are ready to quit being abused by treatments that are only hurting you and not the cancer, you will be ready.  You will know what to do.  Have faith, and keep fighting while you can.  My oldest child is 14, my youngest 3, and it is so hard to think that I won't be here for them every step of their lives.   I just have to remember that although I CHOSE to stop fighting my cancer, I DID NOT CHOSE to have cancer. Posts.Content: Oct 12, 2007 10:56PM mrs_X_Sunneedazee wrote: Hi crazymomof4....  I am a crazymomof5.  Anyway, I have IBC, and first biopsy (a frozen section) came back negative, however the punch biopsy and the lymph node biopsy I had done at the same time came back positive.  From what I have read, IBC is hard to diagnose by biopsy because there is no defined tumor a lot of the time to biopsy.  I had a lot of pain from bone mets in my hip as well, but it is hard to say if your  grandmother-in-law's pain is from old age, arthritis, or something else.  I was brushed off for more than a year before my IBC was finally diagnosed.  My right breast had a large mass the size of a baseball full of cancer before a DR I went to finally took me seriously enough. Because I was a breastfeeding mother, my ob-gyn kept on telling me it was mastitis, engorgement, clogged milk ducts etc.   I thank God every day that I found this site and was able to read about this terribe disease, otherwise I probably wouldn't be alive right now to type this.   I hope that it does turn out to be nothing, but you do need to be agressive and find out what exactly is causing her problem.

I wasn't aware that there are different kinds of ports. I have a 3 inch incision, and mine was quite sore for a  week. It hurt to put my arm up to brush my teeth or wash my hair.  Then it took forever to heal, because they started chemo 4 days after I had it put in.  Then my 1 year old head butted me and split the incision open, then it got infected.  It took about 3 months before it wasn't an ugly oozing wound.    It bugged me at first having this hard thing right under the skin, but I am used to it now.  If my now 2 year old bumps it it still hurts.  People ask me all the time when I am going to get my port removed.  Sadly, I have to tell them....  never....   I wonder if they ever wear out?

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2009 01:46AM mrs_X_Sunneedazee wrote: I logged in tonight and was so very touched by every single word you lovely friends have written for me.  I am so glad that I am not the only one who struggles with these issues and feelings.  Thanks for helping me gain a better prespective of myself and my role as a mother.  I have been placing too much value on what I do or don't do than what I am and can be for my children.  I love their hugs and kisses, and if that is the only thing I can give them, it is enough.  I have spent the day in bed crying and feeling quite sorry for myself, but tonight after reading all of your messages of support, I feel so much better.  I am so grateful for all of you who have taken time to help me in my hour of need.  God bless you all!!!!!   I will have a lengthy discussion with my Onc. about what I can do to get a better handle on the emotional issues, because there is more to health than just physical health.  I am going to try to dig deeper, and pray harder for the strength I need to continue to fight.  I am not ready to die, I am just having a hard time adjusting to my life as it is now.   Thank you all for your kindness and support.  I am so grateful for you all sharing your experiences and personal stories.  It helps to know that I am not a horrible person for having these feelings.  I will be brave and start another week of Xeloda (I have already done 3 weeks of it 1 wk on and 1 wk off) and try to have faith that it will help.  No pain, no gain right?   Thanks again, Love, Amber

Posts.Content: Oct 13, 2007 03:25AM mrs_X_Sunneedazee wrote: I have bone mets.  They are in my hip, spine, pelvis, femur, and ribs.  The pain started in my low back and gradually spread as the cancer did.  From January until May it got worse and worse.  For about 4 months I had so much pain, I couldn't walk, climb stairs, lift my 1 yr old.  I had an MRI in March, it showed nothing but a couple slightly bulging discs.    I don't know if they would have seen the cancer, had they been looking for it, but I was only 28.  The dr who ordered the MRI ordered it to look for bulging discs.  I did physical therapy, epidural injection, therapeutic ultrsound, decompression, but the pain got worse and worse.   I was laying on an ice pad every night along with taking Narcotic pain medicine just to go to sleep.  MISERABLE! My bone mets were dx by a bone scan and confirmed with xray (the day after I was finally dx with breast cancer after  more than a year of being brushed off by dr after dr).  I hope that in your case the pain is not mets, but I wouldn't be put off until they can pin point what is causing your pain.  Good luck!

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2008 12:48PM mrs_X_Sunneedazee wrote: Thank you for all of your prayers, love and support.  I have been having a difficult time with my cancer and chemo, but our community pulled together and did a wonderful fundraiser for our family.  We are going to be able to go on a much needed trip to DisneyLand in early December.  We feel so blessed!!!! I have tried a couple of chemos, and they don't seem to be working, so we have decided to take a break from chemo for a couple of months so I can enjoy the holidays.  The chemo is making me sicker than the cancer, so I am going to only do Herceptin and Zometa and maybe a hormonal, and may think about trying another chemo after Christmas.  We are at peace with this decision, and I look forward to feeling better.  I have a lot of catching up to do, because I have been too ill to be on the computer.  I have missed you all!!! love, Amber

Posts.Content: Sep 26, 2007 10:16PM - edited Sep 26, 2007 10:16PM by mrs_X_Sunneedazee I am sorry to hear of your diagnosis, but know that this place is a wonderful place for info and support.  I was diagnosed 4 months ago, and I had mets at diagnosis to by bones and lung.  I have had great response to the chemo, and actually have better days than before I was diagnosed.  (I was in so much pain from the bone mets.)  I appreciate life so much more now, and don't fret the little things.  My husband actually commented that I am happier now because I look for the good in life, even though I have stage 4 cancer.  I do have hard days when I cry a lot, but all in all I have found peace in my trial.  Good luck to you!

Posts.Content: Nov 6, 2007 08:52PM mrs_X_Sunneedazee wrote: Karen, i checked out your wig pictures.  They are terrific. What a fun time it looked like you had.  It really does help to do the wig thing with family and friends and laugh, and it lightens the sadness.  So, Sue, make sure you do the same thing when you go wig shopping. Fumi, welcome to the group.  We are happy to have you.  I really enjoy this terrfic circle of friends.  Thanks Sue for bringing us all together!!!!  You are such a popular girl.  I am never on at the same time as you. It must be the time difference. Shirlann, you are so lucky to be going on a cruise. I am begging my husband to take me on a cruise once I get all recovered from surgery.  January or february would be great.  We would probably do the last minute booking so to get a good deal, and also less risk of something happening to derail our plans. I am doing great and am off my pain meds!  Yippeee!!!  It is so good to not have pain, only a little.  I had my first weekly herceptin treatment without the taxol today.  I also had zometa.  It is great to not be feeling nauseated or have my hands and feet burning from the taxol.  I was so tired of that. I received my pathology report today also.  There were a couple of spots of cancer left in the breast, so my onc and surgeon are both still recommending 6 weeks of radiation to prevent recurrence on the chest wall.  I was really hoping to get out of radiation.  At least they told me I could wait a couple of months to recover from my dual surgery.   I also have to start taking Aromasin today.  Anyone else taking this??  Have many side effects? I don't know how to post pictures here, but I do have a blog that I posted pictures on, so if anyone would like to check them out, here is the web address... www.amberchase.weebly.com have a great night everyone!!  hugs!

Posts.Content: Nov 27, 2007 06:01PM - edited Nov 27, 2007 06:04PM by mrs_X_Sunneedazee Hi Sue, you should be sleeping!!!  I've missed you.  I have been feeling too good this last week and have been busy "decking the halls" for christmas.  It is so much fun.  Once my hair began to fall out, I kept it in a ponytail to keep it from going everywhere until I finally braved it and shaved it.  My dear husband shaved his head the day before I did mine, and the day I shaved my head my sweet brother came over and let me shave his head.  Then my 3 boys shaved their heads as well.  It was so fun instead of traumatic.  It was still hard (and still is!) to look in the mirror and see the stranger looking back at me.  On the plus side, the savings in hair care and time spent blowdrying and curling my hair has been a blessing.  I'm not sure how to post pictures on this site, but here is a link to the page of my blog where the picture of us all is posted after our headshaving party: You have to scroll all the way to the very bottom amberchase.weebly.com/1/archiv... Hope you can go back to sleep!!!!
